com.helger.jcodemodel

Class JBlock

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.helger.jcodemodel.JBlock
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IJGenerable, IJStatement
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    JLambdaBlock

    public class JBlock
extends Object
implements IJGenerable, IJStatement
    A block of Java code, which may contain statements and local declarations.

    JBlock contains a large number of factory methods that creates new statements/declarations. Those newly created statements/declarations are inserted into the "current position". The position advances one every time you add a new instruction.

      • pos

        @Nonnegative
public int pos()
        Returns:
        the current position to which new statements will be inserted. For example if the value is 0, newly created instructions will be inserted at the very beginning of the block.
        See Also:
        pos(int)

      • pos

        @Nonnegative
public int pos(@Nonnegative
                  int nNewPos)
        Sets the current position.
        Parameters:
        nNewPos - The new position to set
        Returns:
        the old value of the current position.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the new position value is illegal.
        See Also:
        pos()

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Returns:
        true if this block is empty and does not contain any statement.

      • size

        @Nonnegative
public int size()
        Returns:
        The number of elements contained in the block. Always ≥ 0.

        @Nonnull
public JSynchronizedBlock synchronizedBlock(@Nonnull
                                           IJExpression aExpr)
        Create a synchronized block statement and add it to this block
        Parameters:
        aExpr - The expression to synchronize on. May not be null.
        Returns:
        Newly generated synchronized block. Never null.
        Since:
        2.7.10

      • directStatement

        @Nonnull
public IJStatement directStatement(@Nonnull
                                  String sSource)
        Creates a "literal" statement directly.

        Specified string is printed as-is. This is useful as a short-cut.

        For example, you can invoke this method as: directStatement("a=b+c;").

        Parameters:
        sSource - The source code to state. May not be null.
        Returns:
        The created direct statement.
